inlineContent.text: Learn why the Observation framework introduced in Swift 5.9 is a game changer.
Compare the limitations of the existing ObservableObject with the innovations of the new @Observable.

sections.title: Introduction to Observation & Differences from ObservableObject

inlineContent.text: Developers were always confused about when to use
You simply want to track state changes,
but you had to depend on an entire reactive programming framework.
The Combine-based ObservableObject has been with SwiftUI from the beginning,
Let‚Äôs examine why these limitations are problematic through code.
It‚Äôs implemented in pure Swift, making it lighter and more intuitive.
Of course, you can still use it with Combine if needed.
it elegantly solves all the problems mentioned above.
From now on, let‚Äôs build the
We‚Äôll learn how to utilize all of Observation‚Äôs features in practice.
Let‚Äôs set up the project structure and create our first @Observable model.
Create a new iOS project in Xcode.
A simple model containing the product‚Äôs name, price, and quantity.
This will be the main state store used throughout the app.
It includes the product list and total price calculation logic.
ObservableObject notifies changes at the object level,
so it can‚Äôt track precisely which property changed.
All observing views re-render when any @Published property changes
The issue is about performance and complexity.
It can‚Äôt be used on iOS 13 or below
It can‚Äôt be used with struct
The core issue is the lack of observation granularity.
What is the biggest problem with ObservableObject?
What is the key advantage of the Observation framework?
Views only observe properties they actually read, preventing unnecessary updates
This is called ‚ÄúGranular Observation‚Äù and is the most revolutionary part of Observation.
It can be used with struct
Structs are value types, so the observation pattern doesn‚Äôt fit.
because it uses Swift 5.9‚Äôs macro feature.
